Award.AwardTitle: VOSS: Toward a Context Adaptive Theory of the Relationship Between Structural Fluidity and Virtual Organization Performance

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
A major advantage of virtual organizations (VOs) is flexible membership and participation. In many VOs, members are able to join and leave at will, and can change whom they collaborate with at any point in time. This flexibility can be a source of increased effectiveness as VO structures are more readily able to adapt to contingencies and VO leadership can evolve over the course of a VO's lifecycle.
This project examines the relationship between structural fluidity, VO leadership, and VO performance. The investigators will examine the log data generated by the technical systems used for coordination and information sharing in four different types of VOs (software engineering, disaster relief, online learning, and public discourse communities), will interview VO participants, and will measure VO performance in context-specific ways. The project will: (1) develop tools to measure organizational fluidity and make that fluidity visible to VO participants; (2) examine the relationship between organizational performance, the fluidity of group membership and fluidity of leadership in virtual organizations. The techniques pioneered in this proposal will increase understanding of how to use technical system log data to more quickly identify the most effective social structures and leadership strategies in VOs. The results and tools developed in the course of the project will have practical value for those seeking to improve VO performance for science, industry and government organizations that increasingly rely on virtual organizations for their success. A number of undergraduate and graduate students will participate in the project, furthering their training and education in interdisciplinary research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Virtual organizations are prominent in our society, and form an essential component of the US Economy, including professional services, technology, trade, manufacturing, education and governance. This project focused attention on utilizing the electronic trace data (log files) left behind by systems people use, collectively, to embody virtual organizations.

Much of what is known about virtual organizations is known only from these traces. Since they are too voluminous for any individual or group of individuals to make sense of, we aggregated them to construct clear metrics of performance in the areas of disaster response, distributed software development, technology mediated learning and rural IT outsourcing. Our impact is significant in each area.

Data Ethics Sidebar: Across all domains, it is important to recognize that analysis of electronic trace data for the purpose of evaluating human performance requires a human to interpret the indicators. As a weather forecaster takes a number of inputs and estimates the likelihood of snow on a cold and wet January day in Minneapolis, so a human performance forecaster will use our indicators to make estimates. We do not shovel weather forecasts, we shovel snow. We do not judge human performance by the indicators, we use the indicators as an input to human performance evaluation.

In our examination of coordination between government and non-government organizations following the 2011 earthquake and Haiti, we demonstrated how to identify and support brokers of information in critical domains like housing, communications and medical care. Our examination of the flow of accurate and inaccurate information following the Boston Marathon Bombing in 2013 helps informed ongoing work on event detection via machine learning on microblogging sites like Twitter.

Understanding individual and organizational performance in open source software development is a long standing challenge. Our work contributes greater understanding of the role of individual reputation in moving support to new projects: which is significant. We also identified metrics for looking at performance from the perspective of potential contributors, showing how small communication acts early in a new person's participation influence future contributions.

This project developed the first detailed methodology and ontology for the examination of electronic trace data, which we refer to as "Group Informatics." Subsequent work contrasted how participation and affiliation type connections are represented differently on different online collaboration platforms. In our synthesis work, we showed how similar collaboration platforms used similar terms, like "follow" in different ways. If the indicators we develop to assess collaboration across platforms do not take these differences into account, we showed that what is measured is usually not what peoplethink is being measured.

Technology mediated learning environments are the third domain where Group Informatics was applied in this research project. Here our analysis included an asynchronous course management system for distance courses, where our work described metrics for revealing the complex interconnections between individual identity, social identity, group identity, collaboration style and performance on group work. We also reported on the positive effects of a social media tool, Yammer, on supporting face to face group work in a university classroom. Finally, we applied a number of machine learning, data mining and performance predictive algorithms to help instructors facilitating virtual math teams with middle school students identify groups needing more direction.

Our online world is changing how people communicate with, identify with and relate to others. Its affecting work and shifting economic fortunes across all of US Society. If a virtual, global organization can produce the same product for half the cost, that's the organization investors are inclined to create. Shades of this reality color each of the studies sponsored by this project.

One hopeful sign for the US Economy, and US Citizens is the effect of performance indicators for virtual organizations on an emerging industry sector: rural outsourcing of technology work. In the three studies we published in this space, we showed how information and communication technology demonstrated levels of organizational performance and specific returns on investment associated with developing geographically isolated workforces.

Though this project is over, a number of related, new projects are continuing the work and still more have been proposed to various funding agencies. We understand a lot more about performance in virtual organizations than we did before this project, but much work remains to be done.
